According to news originating from London, United Kingdom, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,“ There have been rising concerns in the UK about the levels of serious violence between young people, especially serious physical...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health Policy
and Law Daily \-- Investigators publish new report on Pediatrics. According to
news originating from London, United Kingdom, by NewsRx correspondents,
research stated, "There have been rising concerns in the UK about the levels
of serious violence between young people, especially serious physical violence
and knife crime. Interactions with young people in the emergency department
(ED) at the time of injury provide an opportunity for screening and
intervention in order to reduce the risk of repeat attendances."

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Imperial College
London, "However, paediatricians and other healthcare workers can feel unsure
about the best way to intervene. Embedding youth workers in EDs has started in
some UK hospitals, making use of a potential 'teachable moment' in the
immediate aftermath of an event to help change behaviour. Based on a rapid
review of the literature, we summarise the evidence for these types of
interventions and present two practice examples."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Finally, we discuss
how EDs could approach the embedding of youth workers within their department
and considerations required for this."

For more information on this research see: Young victims of youth violence:
using youth workers in the emergency department to facilitate 'teachable
moments' and to improve access to services. _Archives of Disease In Childhood
Education and Practice Edition_ , 2020;():edpract-2019-318251.

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained
from E. Wortley, School of Public Health, Imperial College London, London, UK.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1136/archdischild-2019-318251>. This DOI is a link to an
online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Research Data from Imperial College London Update Understanding of Pediatrics (Young victims of youth violence: using youth workers in the emergency department to facilitate ‘teachable moments’ and to improve access to services): Pediatrics
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health Policy and Law Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Pediatrics. According to news originating from London, United Kingdom, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “There have been rising concerns in the UK about the levels of serious violence between young people, especially serious physical violence and knife crime. Interactions with young people in the emergency department (ED) at the time of injury provide an opportunity for screening and intervention in order to reduce the risk of repeat attendances.”

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Imperial College London, “However, paediatricians and other healthcare workers can feel unsure about the best way to intervene. Embedding youth workers in EDs has started in some UK hospitals, making use of a potential ‘teachable moment’ in the immediate aftermath of an event to help change behaviour. Based on a rapid review of the literature, we summarise the evidence for these types of interventions and present two practice examples.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Finally, we discuss how EDs could approach the embedding of youth workers within their department and considerations required for this.”

For more information on this research see: Young victims of youth violence: using youth workers in the emergency department to facilitate ‘teachable moments’ and to improve access to services. Archives of Disease In Childhood Education and Practice Edition, 2020;():edpract-2019-318251.

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from E. Wortley, School of Public Health, Imperial College London, London, UK.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1136/archdischild-2019-318251. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
